questions.text: The nitrogen atom of aspartate formed from asparagine using the enzyme asparaginase is from:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The nitrogen atom in asparagine is derived from glutamine via the action of asparagine synthetase, which is analogous to the reaction catalysed by glutamine synthetase, except that it uses glutamine instead of ammonium ions as the nitrogen donor.

  • This explains why asparagine synthetase cannot fix ammonia, unlike glutamine synthetase.
  • In contrast, bacterial asparagine synthetase can also use ammonium ions as a nitrogen source.

Asparagine synthetase: Transfers the amide nitrogen from glutamine to aspartate to form asparagine.

  • Reaction: Aspartate + Glutamine + ATP → Asparagine + Glutamate + AMP + PPi
  • Glutamine serves as an amide group donor, not ammonium.
  • Asparaginase catalyses the reverse reaction, breaking down asparagine to aspartate and releasing ammonia.
  • Clinical relevance: Asparaginase is used in acute lymphoblastic leukaemia treatment, targeting leukemic cells dependent on exogenous asparagine.

Explanation of Other Options:

Ammonium (Option A): Nitrogen source for glutamine synthetase, not for human asparagine synthetase.

Glutamate (Option B): Product of glutamine deamidation; not the direct nitrogen donor in this context.

Alpha-Ketoglutarate (Option D): Involved in transamination reactions and glutamate synthesis, not directly linked to asparagine synthesis.

Key Takeaways:

Glutamine is the nitrogen donor for asparagine synthesis in humans; ammonium is used only in bacteria.

Explanation:

Oxaloacetate is derived from Aspartate and Asparagine, both of which contribute all four carbon atoms to the TCA intermediate.

  • Asparagine is first converted to Aspartate by Asparaginase (hydrolytic deamidation).
  • Aspartate then undergoes transamination to form Oxaloacetate.

Asparagine + H2O → Aspartate + NH4

Aspartate + Pyruvate → Alanine + Oxaloacetate

  • Asparagine → Aspartate: via Asparaginase
  • Aspartate → Oxaloacetate: via Transaminase (AST / Aspartate Transaminase)
  • These steps are key components of glucogenic amino acid catabolism.
  • Glucogenic amino acids are converted into TCA cycle intermediates, such as oxaloacetate, and are involved in gluconeogenesis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Proline (Option A): Yields glutamate, which is further catabolized to α-ketoglutarate, not oxaloacetate.

Histidine and Arginine (Option B): Catabolized to glutamate, leading to α-ketoglutarate formation.

Glutamate and Glutamine (Option C): Degraded to α-ketoglutarate, a TCA intermediate upstream of oxaloacetate.

Key Takeaways:

Aspartate and asparagine are both glucogenic amino acids that contribute to oxaloacetate formation.

questions.text: Which among the following is the essential cofactor required for the formation of hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ascorbic acid plays an important role in the formation of hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine, an integral part of collagen structure.

  • In collagen structure, each polypeptide chain is twisted into a left-handed helix of three residues (Glycine-X-Y) per turn.
  • This repeating structure, represented as (Gly-X-Y)n, is an absolute requirement for the formation of the triple helix.
  • While X and Y can be any other amino acids, the X positions are often proline, and the Y positions are often hydroxyproline.
  • Proline and hydroxyproline confer rigidity on the collagen molecule.
  • Hydroxyproline is formed by the post-translational hydroxylation of peptide-bond proline residues catalysed by the enzyme prolyl hydroxylase, whose cofactors are ascorbic acid (vitamin C) and α-ketoglutarate.
  • Lysines in the Y position may also be post-translational modified to hydroxylysine through the action of lysyl hydroxylase, an enzyme with similar cofactors to prolyl hydroxylase.

Explanation of Other Options:

Pyridoxal phosphate (Option A): Coenzyme in transamination and decarboxylation; not involved in collagen hydroxylation.

Thiamine pyrophosphate (Option C): Cofactor in oxidative decarboxylation reactions (e.g., pyruvate dehydrogenase); unrelated to proline/lysine hydroxylation.

Methylcobalamin (Option D): Active form of vitamin B12, a coenzyme in methylation reactions; not involved in collagen modification.

Key takeaways :

  • Hydroxylation of Proline and Lysine is catalysed by Prolyl Hydroxylase and Lysyl Hydroxylase, respectively, with cofactors that are Vitamin C and α-ketoglutarate.

questions.text: Stickler Syndrome is due to a deficiency of which type of collagen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Stickler syndrome is characterised by abnormal forms of type II collagen due to a mutation in the COL2A1 gene.

  • A defect in Type II collagen results in Chondrodysplasia.
  • Chondrodysplasias are a mixed group of hereditary disorders affecting the cartilage. They are manifested by short-limbed dwarfism and numerous skeletal deformities.
  • A number of them are due to a variety of mutations in the COL2A1 gene, leading to abnormal forms of type II collagen.
  • One example is Stickler syndrome (may also be due to mutations in the COL11A1 and COL11A2 genes), manifested by degeneration of the joint cartilage and of the vitreous body of the eye.

Explanation of other options :

Type I Collagen (Option A):

  • A defect in Type I collagen leads to osteogenesis imperfecta.
  • Also known as Brittle Bone disease or Pseudo Battered Baby syndrome, it is characterised by :
    • Multiple fractures
    • Blue sclera
    • Hearing loss

Type III Collagen (Option C):

  • If Type III Collagen is defective, it leads to Ehler-Danlos Syndrome.
  • Also known as Rubber Man syndrome.
  • However, all types of collagen can be defective in Ehlers-Danlos syndrome:
    • If Type I collagen is involved, it can result in a hypermobile joint.
    • A defect in Type V collagen can cause hyperelastic skin.
  • In Ehler-Danlos Syndrome, there is an increased risk of :
    • MV prolapse
    • Aortic dissection

Type IV Collagen (Option D):

  • Type IV collagen defects lead to Alport syndrome.
  • In Alport syndrome, the Alpha 5 chain is defective.
  • Clinical features :
    • Hematuria
    • Sensorineural hearing loss
    • Anterior Lenticonus

questions.text: All amino acids mentioned below yield succinyl CoA except :
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lysine is a strictly ketogenic amino acid and does not contribute to succinyl-CoA formation.

  • Valine, isoleucine, and methionine are glucogenic or both glucogenic and ketogenic and are known to form succinyl-CoA, an intermediate of the TCA cycle. (Other options are ruled out)
  • Propionyl-CoA, derived from these amino acids, is converted to methylmalonyl-CoA and then to succinyl-CoA via methylmalonyl-CoA mutase.
  • Lysine, on the other hand, is metabolised to acetyl-CoA or acetoacetyl-CoA but never forms TCA cycle intermediates like succinyl-CoA.
  • Amino acids classified as glucogenic yield TCA cycle intermediates (e.g., oxaloacetate, α-ketoglutarate, succinyl-CoA).
  • Lysine and leucine are the only purely ketogenic amino acids.
  • Succinyl-CoA plays a central role in both the TCA cycle and heme synthesis.

Explanation:

At the isoelectric point (pI), a protein or amino acid exists in a zwitterionic form, carrying equal numbers of positive and negative charges- hence, its net charge becomes zero. This condition results in:

  • No migration during electrophoresis
  • Minimum solubility
  • Maximum precipitation
  • Reduced buffering capacity

Explanation of other options:

Migrates (Option B): Proteins do not migrate in an electric field at pI due to the net charge being zero.

Positively charged (Option C ): Occurs only at pH below pI, not at pI.

Negatively charged (Option D): Occurs above the pI, not at pI.

Key Takeaway:

At pI, proteins have no net charge, leading to no electrophoretic mobility and minimal solubility- a principle used in protein purification.

questions.text: Proteins are linear polymers of amino acids. They fold into compact structures. Sometimes, these folded structures associate to form homo- or heterodimers. Which one of the following refers to this associated form?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Quaternary structure refers to the spatial arrangement and interactions of multiple polypeptide subunits within a functional protein. It typically involves:

  • Association of homo- or hetero-polypeptides
  • Stabilisation by noncovalent interactions (hydrophobic interactions, hydrogen bonds, ionic bonds, van der Waals forces)
  • Sometimes, covalent disulfide bonds may be present

Primary Structure

It is the linear sequence of amino acids held together by peptide bonds in its peptide chains. The bond involved in primary structure is the Peptide Bond, a type of covalent bond.

Secondary Structure

  • Configurational relationship between residues that are about 3-4 amino Acids apart in a linear sequence.
  • The folding of short (3 to 30-residue), contiguous segments of polypeptide into geometrically ordered units
  • Bonds involved in the secondary structure are primarily noncovalent bonds, like:
    • Hydrogen Bond (Most important Bond)
    • Hydrophobic Bond
    • Electrostatic Bond (Ionic Bond, Salt Bridges)
    • van der Waals forces.

Tertiary structure: The entire three-dimensional conformation of a polypeptide is referred to as tertiary structure.

Quaternary structure: If more than one polypeptide aggregates to form one functional protein, the spatial relationship between the polypeptide subunits is referred to as quaternary structure.

Bonds involved in Tertiary and Quaternary Structures are primarily noncovalent bonds.

  • Hydrophobic Interaction
  • Hydrogen Bond
  • Electrostatic Bond
  • Van der Waal's Forces

Some covalent bonds may be present, like disulfide bonds (both intra- & inter-strand) and cross-links between side chains of strands.

Explanation of other options:

Denatured state (Option A): Refers to unfolded or structurally disrupted proteins, not native functional assemblies.

Molecular aggregation (Option B): Often refers to nonspecific or pathological protein clumping, not an organised quaternary structure.

Precipitation (Option C): A physical phenomenon due to loss of solubility, not a structural organisation level.

Key Takeaway:

Quaternary structure describes the organised assembly of two or more polypeptide chains into a functional multimeric protein.

questions.text: Which among the following is the structure of myoglobin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Myoglobin is a single-chain globular protein that functions as an oxygen storage molecule in muscle. It consists of only one polypeptide chain and one heme prosthetic group, classifying it as a monomer.

  • It does not exhibit cooperative binding, unlike haemoglobin.
  • The absence of quaternary structure accounts for its hyperbolic oxygen dissociation curve.
  • This structural simplicity supports its rapid oxygen release in hypoxic muscle conditions.

Explanation of other options:

Homodimer (Option A): A homodimer has two identical polypeptide chains, seen in some enzymes, but not in myoglobin.

Heterodimer (Option B): Refers to two different subunits; haemoglobin has heterodimeric α and β chains, but myoglobin does not.

Tetramer (Option C): Haemoglobin is a tetramer (α2β2); myoglobin lacks this multimeric structure.

Key Takeaway:

Myoglobin is a monomeric protein with no quaternary structure and a hyperbolic oxygen-binding curve.

questions.text: In forming a 3D structure following factors help except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Peptide bonds form the primary linear structure but do not directly contribute to tertiary folding.

  • Tertiary and quaternary structures arise from side-chain interactions (hydrophobic, hydrogen, ionic, van der Waals forces) and sometimes disulfide bonds.
  • The amino acid sequence (primary structure) determines the folding pattern, as side chains interact to form complex 3D conformations. (Option B ruled out)
  • Interactions between polypeptide chains are essential for quaternary structure formation. (Option C ruled out)
  • Chaperone proteins assist in proper folding and prevent aggregation of nascent polypeptides. (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaway:

Primary structure (peptide bonds) determines the sequence but is not directly responsible for the folding into tertiary or quaternary structures.

questions.text: An alpha helix of a protein is most likely to be disrupted if a missense mutation introduces the following amino acid within the alpha-helical structure:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Glycine, due to its small side chain and high flexibility, disrupts the stability of the alpha helix by introducing bends or irregularities.

  • The alpha helix is stabilised by hydrogen bonds between the carbonyl oxygen of one residue and the amide hydrogen of the fourth residue ahead.
  • Glycine, being highly flexible with no side chain (just a hydrogen atom), fails to maintain the regular geometry of the helix.

Explanation of other options:

Alanine (Option A): Small, nonpolar side chain; commonly found in alpha helices and stabilises them.

Aspartic acid (Option B): Polar and negatively charged, but does not inherently disrupt the helix unless involved in unfavourable electrostatics.

Tyrosine (Option C): Bulky aromatic side chain, but tolerated within helices if properly positioned.

Key Takeaway:

Glycine disrupts the alpha helix due to its conformational flexibility and lack of side-chain bulk.

choices.text: pH changes are moved away from the isoelectric pH

questions.text: Precipitation of proteins occurs in all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Proteins precipitate maximally at their isoelectric pH, not when moved away from it.

  • Protein precipitation is facilitated when the net charge is neutralised-this occurs at the isoelectric point (pI).
  • At pI, proteins lose their shell of hydration due to a lack of net charge, promoting aggregation.
  • Organic solvents (like alcohol or acetone) remove water, reducing protein solubility and causing precipitation. (Option A ruled out)
  • Trichloroacetic acid and heavy metal salts cause precipitation by denaturing proteins or disrupting hydration shells. (Option C and D ruled out)
  • Moving away from pI increases the net charge on proteins, enhancing their solubility and reducing precipitation.

Methods to precipitate protein by removing the shell of hydration:

  • Precipitation by neutral salts
    • Concentrated Salt solution removes the shell of hydration.
    • The reagents used are Ammonium sulfate. This is called salting out.
  • Precipitation by organic solvents
    • The reagents used are ether, alcohol, acetone, etc.

Key Takeaway:

Precipitation of proteins is most efficient at their isoelectric pH due to loss of net charge and shell of hydration.

choices.text: The Protein has undergone hydrolysis of the S-S linkage
It is a dimer of 2 subunits of 20 and 30 KDa
It is a tetramer of 2,20 KDa and 2,30 KDa
Protein breakdown due to non-covalent linkage

questions.text: Following SDS-PAGE electrophoresis, a protein appears as a single band at 100 kDa. After treatment with Î²-mercaptoethanol, it shows two widely separated bands of 20 kDa and 30 kDa. Which of the following is the most appropriate explanation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A 100 kDa protein that breaks into two subunits (20 kDa and 30 kDa) after β-mercaptoethanol treatment indicates it was a tetramer of covalently linked subunits, specifically 2 of each type.

  • SDS-PAGE separates proteins based on size under denaturing conditions. Without reducing agents, disulfide-linked subunits migrate together.
  • Treatment with β-mercaptoethanol reduces disulfide bonds, allowing subunits to separate and migrate based on individual molecular weights.
  • A 100 kDa protein yielding 20 kDa and 30 kDa subunits suggests a tetrameric structure (2×20 + 2×30 kDa).

Explanation of other options:

Protein has undergone hydrolysis of S-S linkage (Option A): β-mercaptoethanol reduces (does not hydrolyse) disulfide bonds.

It is a dimer of 2 subunits of 20 and 30 kDa (Option B): 20 + 30 = 50 kDa, not 100 kDa.

Protein breakdown due to non-covalent linkage (Option D): SDS denatures proteins and breaks non-covalent bonds. Disulfide bonds are covalent.

Key Takeaway:

SDS-PAGE with reducing agents like β-mercaptoethanol reveals covalently linked multimeric subunits of a protein.

questions.text: The methods used to study the structure of proteins include all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Edman reaction enables peptides & proteins to be sequenced.

  • Edman's reaction is used to detect the sequence of amino acids in a polypeptide.
  • Pehr Edman introduced phenylisothiocyanate (Edman reagent) to selectively label the amino-terminal residue of a peptide.
  • In contrast to the Sanger reagent, the phenylisothiohydantoin (PTH) derivative can be removed under mild conditions to generate a new amino-terminal residue.
  • Successive rounds of derivatisation with the Edman reagent can therefore be used to sequence many residues of a single sample of peptide.
  • Even so, the determination of the complete sequence of a protein by chemical methods remains a time- and labour-intensive process.

Explanation of other options:

UV Spectroscopy (Option A): Used to study structural features by analysing the absorbance of aromatic side chains.

NMR Spectroscopy (Option B): An advanced method for determining tertiary and quaternary structures of proteins in solution.

X-ray Crystallography (Option C): Gold standard for detailed 3D structural elucidation of crystallised proteins.

questions.text: In SDS-PAGE, proteins are separated based on:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

SDS binds uniformly to proteins and neutralises their native charges, allowing separation purely based on molecular mass.

  • SDS (sodium dodecyl sulfate) is a strong anionic detergent that denatures proteins and imparts a uniform negative charge proportional to protein length.
  • This masks the intrinsic charges of proteins, ensuring that migration in polyacrylamide gel is governed solely by molecular weight.
  • Smaller proteins migrate faster through the gel matrix, while larger ones migrate more slowly.
  • SDS-PAGE can also be paired with reducing agents like 2-mercaptoethanol or dithiothreitol to break disulfide bonds in multimeric proteins.

Explanation of other options:

Charge (Option B): Native PAGE separates proteins by charge and size, but SDS-PAGE masks intrinsic charge.

Density (Option C): Not relevant to SDS-PAGE; density is not a separation criterion.

Solubility (Option D): Solubility plays no role in SDS-PAGE migration.

Key Takeaway:

SDS-PAGE separates proteins based on molecular mass alone by equalising their charge-to-mass ratio.

questions.text: Amino acid sequence is not found by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Amino acid sequence determination is not performed by Benedict's reagent, which is a test for reducing sugars.

Methods of Protein Sequencing:

Sanger's Technique

  • Sanger's Reagent is 1, Fluoro 2, 4 Dinitrobenzene
  • Sanger's Reagent derivatises the amino-terminal residues.
  • The first Protein to be sequenced by the method is Insulin by Fredrick Sanger. He got the Nobel Prize in 1958.
  • Only dipeptides or tripeptides can be sequenced.

Edman's Technique

  • By using Edman's Reagent (Phenyl Iso-Thio-cyanate).
  • Phenyl Isothiocyanate derivatives are the amino terminal of a Polypeptide.
  • Edman's Technique can sequence many residues (5-30 residues) of a single polypeptide sample, unlike Sanger's

Explanation of other options:

Sanger's reagent (Option A): Labels the N-terminal amino acid to identify it during sequencing.

Trypsin (Option C): Cleaves polypeptides at specific sites to generate peptides for sequencing.

Cyanogen bromide (Option D): Specifically cleaves at methionine residues to aid sequence analysis.

Key Takeaway:

Benedict's reagent is a carbohydrate detection reagent and plays no role in protein or peptide sequencing.

questions.text: Molecules up to size 4 kDa are identified by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Quadrupole mass spectrometry is best suited for detecting molecular species of 4000 Da or less.

  • Quadrupole analysers use oscillating electric fields to filter ions by mass-to-charge (m/z) ratio.
  • Particularly effective for low-mass molecules and is used in targeted proteomics and small peptide detection.
  • These systems operate with high resolution and speed, ideal for molecules under 4 kDa.
  • It is the standard for low-mass detection in contrast to TOF-MS.

Explanation of other options:

Gene array chip (Option A): Identifies gene expression by nucleic acid hybridisation, and has no role in mass determination.

Electrospray ionisation (Option B): An ionisation method that converts large molecules into ions for MS but does not itself analyse mass or define detection limits.

Matrix-assisted laser desorption ionisation (Option D): Suitable for ionising large macromolecules for MS analysis, but not ideal for precise quantification of small molecules like those under 4 kDa.

Key Takeaway:

Quadrupole mass spectrometry is the method of choice for detecting molecules up to 4 kDa.

questions.text: Collagen of which type is found in hyaline cartilage?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hyaline cartilage is predominantly composed of type II collagen, which provides resistance to intermittent pressure and tensile strength.

  • Type II collagen forms fine fibrils that aggregate with proteoglycans, contributing to the load-bearing property of cartilage.
  • It is found in articular surfaces, costal cartilage, nasal cartilage, and the embryonic skeleton.
  • This type is crucial in endochondral ossification and cartilage repair mechanisms.

Types of Collagen:

  • Major Collagen present in Bone-Type I (90%)
  • Major Collagen present in Dermis, ligaments and tendons-Type I (80%)
  • Major Collagen present in Cartilage-Type II (40-50%)
  • Major Collagen present in Hypertrophic Cartilage- Type X
  • Major Collagen present in Aorta-Type I and Type III (20-40% each)
  • Major Collagen present in Basement Membrane Type IV
  • Most abundant Collagen-Type I
  • Major Collagen in Keloid is Type 3 >> Type 1

Collagen in Wound Healing: At first, a provisional matrix containing fibrin, plasma fibronectin, and type III collagen is formed, but this is replaced by a matrix composed primarily of type I collagen

Explanation of other options:

Type I (Option A): Found in skin, tendon, bone, and cornea; not the main collagen in cartilage.

Type III (Option C): Found in reticular fibres, blood vessels, fetal skin, and early wound healing.

Type IV (Option D): Forms mesh-like networks in the basement membrane, not in cartilage.

Key Takeaway:

Type II collagen is the principal collagen type in hyaline cartilage, crucial for its resilience and structure.

Explanation:

Signal peptides target proteins to the ER membrane, and the translocon forms the channel through which they are cotranslationally translocated.

  • Signal recognition particle (SRP) binds to the signal peptide as it emerges from the ribosome.
  • SRP guides the ribosome-nascent chain complex to the SRP receptor on the ER membrane.
  • The complex then docks onto the Sec61 translocon, a multi-protein complex forming a gated pore.
  • Translation resumes, and the polypeptide is translocated through the translocon into the ER lumen.
  • The signal peptide is then cleaved by signal peptidase.
  • TRAM is Translocating Chain-Associated Membrane Protein. TRAM accelerates the translocation of certain proteins.
  • TRAP, Translocon-associated Protein Complex. The function of TRAP is not clear.

Explanation of other options:

Chaperone (Option B): Involved post-translationally in protein folding and preventing aggregation, not signal-guided translocation into the ER.

Ubiquitin (Option C): Tags misfolded or damaged proteins for degradation via the proteasome, not part of the ER translocation.

Mannose 6 Phosphate (Option D): Targets proteins to lysosomes via the Golgi apparatus, not the ER membrane.

Key Takeaway:

Translocon (Sec61 complex) is the ER membrane channel responsible for the cotranslational translocation of nascent peptides directed by signal sequences.
